bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the Photographic Department, Signal Corps, December 30, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests permission to examine the photographs that the Signal Corps of the Army took at Columbia Barracks, the Post Hospital and Camp Lazear from 1899 to 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the Photographic Department, Signal Corps, December 30, 1941
div1.opener:
December 30, 1941
Chief of the Photographic Department
Signal Corps
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
For four years I have been making a study of the history of the conquest
of yellow fever, particularly of the work of Major Walter Reed and his colleagues
in Havana, at the Camp Columbia, Post Hospital and at Camp Lazear, in the years
1900 and 1901. I have written a couple of papers on this, one of which I enclose
as an evidence of my interest. I have uncovered a considerable amount of unpub-
lished material, thanks largely to the immediate relatives of the members of the
Army Yellow Fever Board, Mrs. Walter Reed and her daughter, Dr. Agramonte's daughter,
Mrs. Lazear, Dr. Lazear's widow, also former Surgeon General Ireland, Brigadier
General (retired) Jefferson R. Kean, and Brigadier General (retired) Albert E.
Truby. The latter two have mentioned to me various old records that I might find
in Washington and on a previous visit to Washington last Spring I found consider-
able material in the Archives building.

I am very anxious to be permitted to look over the old photographs which
the Signal Corps of the Army took at Columbia Barracks, the Post Hospital and
Camp Lazear from 1899 to 1901. A few of these pictures appear in the Surgeon
General's reports for 1899, 1900 and 1901. It is at the suggestion of General
Kean that I write you.

I intend to be in Washington for a few days about January 13. Would it
be possible for me to see your photographic files of these particular items at
that time? As I will be leaving here January 8, I would appreciate it greatly
if you would send me an airmail reply, using the enclosed envelope.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
